title: Wednesday, 28th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Let's go direct to the scene of the crime

PM

11:02 am
PM

Now, if you read that takeover report you'd possibly notice that Adecco is mis-spelt in the very first word of the opening sentence.

PM

But then who am I to talk about spelling?!?

PM

But just to be 100% clear

11:03 am
PM

The story is a fake

PM

This sort of stuff is out of control

PM

Twitter handles behind this one wold appear to be...

https://twitter.com/AimCasino

PM

https://twitter.com/AimCasino/status/781028607976144896

And possibly https://twitter.com/kevin_galliard, although he/she/it has deleted related tweets

11:05 am
PM

Back in the day, as a financial journalist, you'd sometimes get scrawled notes in the post, saying X is bidding for Y

PM

Or you'd get someone on the phone, talking thru a sock, saying Y is bidding for Z

PM

And you'd just ignore it

11:05 am
PM

Now that everyone can self publish, you've got crap everywhere

PM

Luckily the FCA is on the case

PM

“Six months on and, in a great many cases, firms have made a substantial effort to get this right and embrace the importance of the key principles underlying the Senior Managers and Certification Regime, namely responsibility and accountability.

11:06 am
PM

“Knowing who is responsible for what is critical for firms and regulators and we have seen genuine engagement on this from the Board down.

PM

“Generally, we have observed that firms are taking their responsibilities seriously and have broadly got the regime right. But we recognise culture change takes time and there is still more to do. So we have to keep a watchful eye on the progress firms are making.”

PM

Responsibility, accountability and governance in financial services firms and their impact on conduct has been, and remains, a priority for the FCA with a focus on the most significant drivers of good or poor mindsets and behaviours. This includes incentives and remuneration, and the steps firms take which address associated risks.

11:06 am

Or not

PM

Here's this morning's price action in RTC, for what it's worth

Why rob a bank, risking 10 years in jail?

BE

They're not that stupid, surely?

11:11 am
PM

he merger of Lürssen and Blohm+Voss (the latter owned by the UK’s STAR Capital), two leading superyacht shipyards, was today announced in Germany.

Lürssen, a German family-owned business, built the world’s largest mega-yacht, Azzam (see: http://www.luersse...en/yachts/gallery), whilst B+V built Eclipse, previously the world’s largest mega-yacht. (for recent B+V boat images see: http://www.blohmvo...ht-portfolio.html).

The merger, which is subject to German merge control approval, will create German national champion in Naval Engineering focused on ship-building, maintenance and refit for both civilian and military markets.

BE

Ah, superyachts.

PM

11:11 am
PM

PM

The title to that picture tells me the code name for this merger was Project Jazz

BE

................. oh.

11:12 am
PM

Here's something tho: the secondary market in superyachts seems to be collapsing

PM

Or at least prices are being slashed

PM

http://www.superya...nd-blind-date-sold

11:13 am
PM

Commencing 2016 with a price tag of €175 million, Solandge, currently for sale with Moran Yacht & Ship, is now for sale at €155 million. Launched at the German yard’s Bremen facility in October 2013, she amasses 2,899 gross tons over six decks – an interior volume equivalent to around six 40–50m superyachts.

BE

What I'm most interested in here is that there's a megayacht, which I guess must be bigger than a superyacht.

PM

A megayacht, eh?

11:14 am
BE

One assumes this trend towards yacht inflation will require new terminology. A humungyacht, maybe.

BE

I've also noticed that the more one types the word yacht, the more wrong it looks.

PM

(Reminds me of the one time I met Richard Desmond -- he had a copy of a How To Spend it superyacht special in his hand. I said: "Thinking of making a purchase." He looked at me and said: "Don't you know the three Fs?". I do now.)

11:16 am
PM

Yes, it's a very odd word

BE

"The three Fs"?

BE

(@Flaneur: spam filter's hyperactive at times. We didn't see the comment so have no idea what you said that might've set it off.)

11:17 am
BE

Or should we move on. I think we should probably move on. Let's move on.

undefined

Ok

11:18 am

German government have contingency plans not to let DB fail.

BE

Which is one of those stories that'd be news either way. If Germany didn't have contingency plans that'd be equally interesting.

BE

(@Flaneur: why is the NHS issuing bonds itself in any way preferable to than the government issuing gilts and using them to fund the NHS?)

11:22 am
BE

But we should start with the actual Deutsche Bank news, rather than the shadow boxing of people close to things saying noncommittal things.

BE

As in, Deutsche selling Abbey Life to Phoenix Life

PM

https://www.ft.com...-a29c-6e7d9515ad15

11:25 am
BE

People telling me that the Phoenix rights issue is the biggest ever to fund an acquisition, which doesn't sound right but it's what I'm told.

BE

As in, for the UK market.

PM

Eh?

11:25 am
Phoenix Group Holdings (PHNX:LSE): Last: 864.50, up 26 (+3.10%), High: 870.00, Low: 835.50, Volume: 456.45k
BE

Perhaps I misunderstood. Might just be the biggest this year. Anyway, it's gone down pretty well.

PM

I guess cash call funded acquisitions are often after the fact -- as in the bank supplies a bridging loan and the rights issue comes later

11:26 am
BE

Here's Canaccord to talk us through it from the Phoenix side.

BE

Phoenix announced on Wednesday the acquisition of Abbey Life from Deutsche Bank.
It is paying £935m for £1.6bn in future cashflows, equal to 0.89x Solvency II own funds
end-June and 0.77x embedded value end-December. The book splits c.60% unit linked,
30% annuities, and 10% with-profits, all businesses Phoenix knows well. The additional
cashflows are allowing a 5% increase in the dividend from interim 2017, on top of the 5%
Final 2016 increase post the yet-to-close Axa SunLife deal.
Abbey is being funded by a £735m rights issue (a 7 for 12 at 508p) and a new £250m
bank facility at 85bps over LIBOR. The funding should bring Phoenix's leverage into its
target 25-30% range. The offer document will be mid-October, shareholder vote and ex-
rights end-October, and the deal is expected to close by year-end.

BE

Stronger solvency, dividend de-risking
The CFO indicated at this morning's meeting that management actions would strengthen
the pro-forma solvency II ratio above the 151% pro-forma (up from 144% Phoenix stand-
alone). He stressed the even cashflows from Abbey would support the dividend well
beyond 2020 - on today's disclosure, assuming no debt refinancing, projected cashflows
cover the new £197m annual dividend more than 20x. He did not quantify the impact to
solvency sensitivities, but indicated part of the additional equity risk had already been
hedged. Other major risks are credit, persistency, and interest rate risk in the pension
scheme. Other risk mitigation includes a £175m indemnity against fines and some costs
from the on-going FCA investigation into treatment of longstanding customers.

11:26 am
BE

A sensible deal, with upside to our view of fair value
We re-iterate our Buy recommendation on the transaction. It looks like Phoenix is paying
a reasonable price for a steady return asset, with upside to today's numbers on capital
and cashflows, albeit we look for more disclosure on downside risk scenarios. Simply
taking a pro-forma view of new shares issued and 5% uplift to the dividend, on an
unchanged target dividend yield of 6%, would imply a fair value of 1,025p. Against this,
a shareholder would have to weigh the possibility that dividend growth from the raised
level could require an additional material transaction, with further funding requirements.

BE

And Cazenove.

BE

Phoenix this morning announced the acquisition of Abbey Life for £935m.
The deal is expected to be funded by a £735m fully underwritten rights
issue and a £250m debt facility. The deal is expected to deliver £1.6bn of
cash flows to Phoenix Group (£0.5bn between 2016-2020 and the rest later
on), and consequently, Phoenix has raised its dividend by 5%.
Management expects the deal to improve the Solvency II ratio to 151% on
a pro forma basis and modestly reduce the leverage ratio on a Fitch ratings
basis.

11:27 am
PM

(FATDAZ -- wasn't it an all stock offer?)

BE

 Details of the deal - Phoenix has announced the acquisition of Abbey
Life for £935m, to be funded by a £735m fully underwritten rights issue
and a £250m debt facility with L+85bps cost. The acquisition price
reflects 0.89x Solvency II own funds and 0.77x MCEV. The deal is
expected to be completed by end of 2016. Abbey Life is a closed life
business in the UK with £10bn of assets of which £7.3bn is unit linked,
£2.5bn is annuities and £0.5bn is with profits.

BE

 Cash flows and dividends - Phoenix expects to generate £1.6bn cash
flows overtime from Abbey Life, of which it has guided for £0.5bn cash
flows between 2016-2020 and the remaining £1.1bn cash flows post
2021. Driven by increased cash flows, Phoenix has proposed to increase
the dividend per share by 5%. Management remains comfortable that
cash flows from the back book cover the dividend, debt interest and
repayment, operating and pension-related expenses.

11:27 am
BE

 Solvency II and leverage – Management expects the deal to increase the
Solvency II ratio to a pro forma 151% versus 144% reported at 1H16,
and the leverage is expected to decline marginally on a Fitch ratings
basis. As Abbey Life is currently on a standard model under Solvency II,
Phoenix is looking to apply an internal model with transitional measures
in 2H17 and expects synergies from a change in asset allocation strategy
and matching adjustment measures.

BE

(@Boncoeur: look at the level of financial clusterflux at, for example, St George's Trust and then try to tell me that's a good idea.)

BE

Meanwhile, from the DB side, there's not much else new to day.

11:31 am
BE

Caz has a long and baffling note about derivatives strategies and what's being priced in for DB's stress, but I won't pretend to understand it.

PM

Don't tell me -- the pdf has baffled your computer

BE

McAfee. It's a plague. An actual plague.

11:32 am
PM

Get a Mac

BE

It's not the fact that it's a PC that's the problem. It's the way that PC has been configured.

11:33 am
BE

BE

See? There you go. Totally useful and worth waiting for.

We should look at Sainbury

PM

Sainsbury even

PM

Interims

PM

http://www.investe...1609280700100117L/

PM

11:34 am
BE

Mixed news. Argos looks to be improving but core is a bit weak.

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

PM

Think Argos has only just completed

11:36 am
BE

Yep, though given Sainsbury's changes to the business will be minimal for a few years one can see that stabilisation as quite positive.

PM

sure

BE

Jefferies can summarise from here.

11:36 am
BE

An in-line Q2 sales update... as JS reported supermarket LFL sales growth of -1.1%
(vs JEFe/cons of -1.1%/-1%). This is well below the +2% recently reported by MRW, and
the +0.5% we expect for Tesco's Q2. Improving trading standards at the latter and an
increased Southern expansion focus by discounters are likely key factors behind the JS
underperformance. Argos saw better-than-expected Q2 LFL sales of +2.3% (JEFe +0.5%),
with industry data suggesting market conditions have been rather helpful this summer in
some of Argos's key product categories. Comments around full-year consensus expectations (pre-Argos cons £517m/JEFe £529m) have been postponed to the November interim update and at this juncture our model remains struck on a pre-Argos basis.

BE

...highlighting challenges at the core. As detailed above, JS's core has seen relative
performance progressively deteriorate in recent quarters. This morning's call highlighted
strong non-food sales increases at Sainsbury (of +4%). It is this, now pretty concerning,
dynamic that remains front of mind, rather than the notable progress achieved in building
the group's success in non-food.

BE

Valuation implies Argos failure. A stand-alone SBRY on 13x 2017 cal PE and c.9%
FCY reflects considerable investor scepticism of the rationale behind the Argos acquisition.
Considering that SBRY still targets Argos to deliver, at maturity of integration, double-
digit earnings accretion and low to mid-teens ROCE, it follows that such an outcome is
considered over-optimistic (with this caution presumably also reflecting concerns around
profit pressures in core supermarkets). Some of the caution is well founded given sourcing
and demand risks. But ultimately more due diligence is required from us to review the group
merits, and ahead of that we stay on Hold.

11:38 am
PM

I see Clive Black has put his recommendation under review

PM

Uncertain times
On present market conditions, noting the devaluation of sterling, Sainsbury’s CEO, Mike Coupe, states:
‘We expect the market to remain competitive and the effect of the devaluation of sterling remains unclear. However,
Sainsbury’s is well positioned to navigate the changing marketplace and we are confident that our strategy will
enable us to continue to outperform our major peers’, noting that on a same-store basis in very recent times that the
core Sainsbury grocery business is quite materially underperforming Morrison+ (MRW, House Stock at 220p) and
most probably Tesco UK (TSCO, Hold at 179p) on a LFL sales basis (Morrison reported Q2 LFL sales 2.0% ahead
and we expect Tesco UK to beat Sainsbury’s same store performance with a broadly flat outcome).
That said, and to be fair to Sainsbury in a relative context, the group has not had the dramatic ebbs and flows of its
superstore competitors over the last seven or eight years. As such, Sainsbury may be under-performing some of the
Big Four superstore competitors in recent times, but it has not endured a collapse of same-store volume in those
years, a base that needs to be kept in mind when comparisons are made

PM

This is Shore of course

11:39 am
PM

Clive needs to edit himself

PM

He's too long winded

PM

Forecasts under review
The Q2 FY2017 update, which as stated above is a little mellow for the core chain, albeit from a revenue perspective
is sound for Argos, plus the completion of the acquisition, leads us to put our near and longer-term Sainsbury’s
forecasts under review.
Intuitively, we can envisage a scenario where we downgrade our core chain profit expectations but bolster or
upgrade medium-term group earnings forecasts, to factor in the benefits from the Argos acquisition. We note that
present consensus relates only to Sainsbury of old, that is it is not including Argos, with further information on the
new group performance set to be delivered at the November interim results. As such, it is not unreasonable to assert
that present consensus is pretty meaningless.
Management has, to its credit, provided helpful guidance for some of the financial implications for the Argos
transaction to date, albeit the devaluation of sterling needs to be considered with respect to the ongoing cost of
goods, gross margin and sales volumes of Argos in due course. Accordingly, we intend to come back to the market
with new forecasts and a revisit of our recommendation on Sainsbury’s stock once we have completed this work in
the near future.

11:39 am
PM

Stock down 3.2% live

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 241.90, down 8.9 (-3.55%), High: 254.50, Low: 241.60, Volume: 5.56m

When? Tuesday, 10th January 2017 at 2:00pm for 2:30pm start

Where? London Marriott Hotel Grosvenor Square - London W1K 6JP

11:42 am
undefined
BE

Should note the non superyacht M&A, namely Deutsche Post DHL buying UK Mail.

UK Mail Group PLC (UKM:LSE): Last: 440.51, up 133.01 (+43.26%), High: 440.75, Low: 439.25, Volume: 4.54m
11:43 am
PM

Oh, blimey, missed this

BE

Deutsche Post going back into the UK market, having quite recently quit it as being fundamentally unprofitable.

BE

And paying a quite aggressive price as well.

11:44 am
PM

Clearly

BE

RBC can talk us through the detail.

BE

Our view: Deutsche Post DHL and UK Mail have announced an agreed
offer for UK Mail at 440p/share, vs. yesterday's close of 307.5p (+43%). DP-
DHL have also received irrevocable undertakings from the Kane family and
other shareholders representing ~60% of the UK Mail shareholder base.
Should a competing offer arise, around 13% of the undertakings will be
suspended until DPDHL match/beat a competing offer (within 14 days).

11:44 am
BE

• This price implies c 20x 16/17E PER and 10x EV/EBITDA. On
‘normalised’ earnings this represents c 14x PER, 7.5x EV/EBITDA. The
offer price is still significantly below our upside valuation of 800p (half of
which is predicated on Whistl leaving the market, half on getting parcels
to a 15% margin – 04/05 levels), thus suggesting significant scope for
value creation through internally delivered synergy, before any DHL
Express volume feed which might be added. DP-DHL have also received
irrevocable undertakings from the Kane family and other shareholders
representing ~60% of the UK Mail shareholder base.

BE

• The total cost to DP-DHL is around £240m/€275m, thus is small in the
group context, but it does mark re-entry into a business area which
the company had previously sold its interests in (downstream access
mail and domestic UK parcel delivery, although this appears a PeP
acquisition, not an Express acquisition, under which the UK business
previously fell).

BE

• UK Mail operates in two business areas. (1) Mail: this is a downstream
access business, whereby they take large bulk mail contracts, sort
them and deliver to Royal Mail for final mile access. This market is
dominated by UK Mail and Whistl, accounting for around 45% of all
mail volumes (even though Royal Mail delivers 99.9% through the final
mile). (2) Parcels (5% mkt share): historically a B2B player, in recent
years it has followed the growth in the market towards B2C, and
recently implemented a change from a cage based sorting process to
a centralised automated sorting system. Implementation of this did
not realise initially expected savings, resulting in management turnover
and a delay to cost savings being realised. UK Mail put heavy focus on
customer parcel visibility and ease of use (1 hour delivery slots, live
tracking, in-flight options) and generally carry higher value items than
UK average (no Amazon volume).

11:46 am
BE

Note that stat. Royal Mail, 99.9% final-mile market share. Privatisation was a triumph of trust in regulators to regulate efficiently, which seems to be founded on hope rather than experience.

BE

Back to RBC.

BE

Network offers cost advantage: The company gains an advantage vs.
competitors as it operates both Mail and Parcels through its core
network (each broadly equal in revenue terms around £230-250m),
while competitors generally have dedicated networks. DHL’s previous
experiences in the UK were as a dedicated parcel provider and from a
similar market share were unable to deliver similar profitability.

11:47 am
BE

PT to 440p: Our price target moves up to 440p to match the offer for
the company (we saw one of the US operators as a natural suitor but
these have now largely filled their UK ‘gaps’ through other acquisitions
and organic growth thus see a competing offer as relatively unlikely).

PM

So no counter bid here

BE

Nice chart on market share:

11:48 am
BE

PM

(btw Genny -- Gomorrah bloody terrific telly)

BE

The response to having a better funded competitor is ....

11:48 am
Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 489.10, down 13.9 (-2.76%), High: 505.00, Low: 488.80, Volume: 2.38m
BE

And Credit Suisse .............

BE

Bulking up in the UK e-commerce market – spending 2016E's FCF: DP
DHL highlights UK Mail's complementary fit to their integrated UK offering
and it aims to use UK Mail's platform of 50 sites and 2,400 vehicles to
expand its presence in the UK e-commerce market. (UK, France and
Germany accounts for 60% of European online retail). UK Mail has recently
invested in additional capacity and IT alongside product and service
innovation – however this transition has been challenging due to significant
hub and transport inefficiencies which resulted in a change in operations
management. We also note that this deal should reduce DP DHL FCF
expectations for 2016E and may temper expectations for excess cash
distributions – we forecast €0.5bn in FCF in 2016E pre-UK Mail (€1.5bn pre-
exceptional pensions funding), versus €1.7bn in 2015A.

11:50 am
BE

They're sellers of DP.

BE

Underperform with a TP of €23.40: DP DHL trades on a 2016E-2017E
EV/EBITDA multiple of 10x-9x, representing a premium to 3-5Y averages of
8-8.5x, whereas its 2016E EV/CE and EV/IC multiples of 1.2x and 1.6x look
expensive relative to lease-adjusted ROCE/WACC and ROIC/WACC
multiples of 0.9x and 1.3x.

undefined
11:50 am

Seen this easyHotel rights?

PM

£38m

PM

easyHotel plc (LSE: EZH) ("easyHotel" or the "Company" and together with its subsidiaries, the "Group"), the owner, developer, operator and franchisor of "super budget" branded hotels, today announces a conditional placing of up to 38,000,000 new ordinary shares of 1.0 pence each ("Ordinary Shares") in the capital of the Company (the "Placing Shares") at a price of 100.0 pence per Placing Share (the "Placing Price") to raise £38.0 million (before expenses) (the "Placing").

The Placing Shares represent approximately 60.8 per cent. of the Ordinary Shares in issue as at the date hereof ("Existing Ordinary Shares") and the Placing Price represents a premium of approximately 18.3 per cent. to the closing mid-market price of 84.5 pence per Existing Ordinary Share on 27 September 2016, being the latest practicable date prior to the publication of this Announcement.

BE

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 877.00, up 29.5 (+3.48%), High: 878.00, Low: 855.00, Volume: 2.05m
PM

883 live

11:56 am
BE

We flagged up the Kepler upgrade overnight in the paper, which is an interesting read.

BE

But the argument we highlighted was, "it's cheaper than it was so Murdoch take another run at it". It wasn't some deep market intelligence suggesting such a thing is actually happening.

BE

Onto it we can note two things, though.

11:58 am
BE

First, Sky has an investor day on October 20.

BE

This is notable because Sky doesn't do investor days.

BE

As in, ever. As in, even going back to the BSB Squarial days, it's had none. Zero.

11:59 am
BE

The message is likely to be about squeezing the customer base out of more money.

BE

This Sky-Q box thing -- which bridges the gap between satellite and OTA -- is apparently quite popular.

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley's preview.

12:00 pm
BE

We expect a focus on the broadening of the product base across the Sky companies
and the bigger market opportunity available to Sky post the acquisition of Sky
Deutschland and Sky Italia.

BE

Darroch is positive on the expansion away from the traditional pay TV model which has
been the mainstay product for the last 25 years but where growth has inevitably slowed
as that market has become more mature. On Now TV Darroch commented in an
interview earlier this year: “We found that it has proved to be very complementary, so our
traditional direct-to-home business continues to grow. Now TV is a way that we are
opening up new customer segments and targeting different types of people.' (Variety - April
2016).
Sky's own research indicates that 90% of Now TV customers have not previously
considered taking 'full fat' pay TV services. The argument is thus that Now TV is
extending the pay market in the UK. Extending the market opportunity: The market
rightly has its doubts over the expansion into Europe. SkyD/Sky Italia were purchased
for £7.35bn in 2014 but the acquired companies produced just €54m of EBITA in FY16.
For Sky though the argument is that these companies offer substantial medium term
opportunity. The UK is relatively mature in terms of pay TV penetration but Italy and
Germany offer considerable upside.

BE

Etc.

12:01 pm
BE

The second point to note with Sky is the Royal Television Society conference yesterday.

BE

Which was all about how cord cutting isn't a problem in Europe and they were all moving to non linear anyway.

BE

Exane, which says it was the only sellside there, says ..............

12:02 pm
BE

Participants argued that the race towards non-linear consumption will bring new challenges but ultimately increase engagement, bringing monetisation opportunities. As expected, ITV, Sky and peers robustly defended the sustainability of their respective revenue models. Increasing demand for flagship drama is also significantly impacting the global TV production market. Many UK producers focus on UK centric content (short episode runs, UK themes) but both Sky and ITV have embraced the international opportunity. For example, the Sky Vision MD outlined their targeting of co-production deals (HBO, Canal etc) and 8-10 episode series. We estimate Sky will generate cGBP100m in production revenue, with a boost from the new British Bake-off deal with Channel 4.

BE

Both Sky and ITV have underperformed media in 2016 on structural/cyclical fears. Per our report Fortitude we argue Sky offers attractive mid-single digit revenue growth at just 10x 18 EBITA.

BE

So, that.

12:02 pm
undefined
PM

I think we're done

PM

Sorry if a bit scratchy today

12:03 pm
PM

Back tomorrow tho

PM

11am sharp

PM

Bye!

11:34 am
